awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract: 
Heat transfer is ubiquitous and plays an important role in our daily lives and industrial processes, such as cooling of computer chips and heating of buildings. In classical textbooks of thermal physics, it is well known that the dominant mode of heat transfer in solids is heat conduction, which is known to be slow (travels at around the speed of sound) and diffusive (non-directional). This project studies a new heat conduction mechanism that combines the light in vacuum and sound in solids to conduct heat at high speed (on the order of speed of light) and with a high degree of directionality. The study is important as it may contribute to diverse applications such as more efficient thermal management of computer chips, light emitting diodes, and buildings. By integrating photonics, thermal science, and nanotechnologies, the project provides an excellent interdisciplinary platform to educate and train female graduate students in physics and engineering and offers attractive hands-on laboratory experience for undergraduate and local high-school students from underrepresented minority groups.  

Technical Abstract: 
Heat conduction in solids is normally described as a diffusion process with short mean free path (MFP < 10 microns) associated with the main heat carriers, such as phonons and electrons. The goal of this project is to theoretically and experimentally investigate extraordinary thermal transport phenomena in a new regime of heat conduction mediated by surface phonon polariton (SPhP), which originates from the coupling between optical phonon and photon. SPhP is highly confined along the interface between a polar dielectric material and its surroundings and thus can carry high energy flux, comparable to or even higher than that of phonons in a solid. Under suitable conditions, SPhP can have extremely long propagation lengths (mm or longer) even at room and high temperature, and therefore, can exhibit extraordinary behaviors over a much longer distance. The project utilizes novel experimental techniques in nanoscale device fabrication and high-resolution nano-watt calorimetry, combined with rigorous theoretical modeling and numeric simulation, to explore extraordinary SPhP heat conduction phenomena in polar dielectric nanostructures, including low-dimensional heat conduction,  non-diffusive and quantum thermal transport, and dynamically tunable thermal transport.

This Division of Materials Research (DMR) grant supports research to investigate extraordinary thermal transport phenomena in a new regime of heat conduction mediated by surface phonon polariton with funding from the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Program in the DMR of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Heat transfer is a fundamental physical process with broad implications across engineering and science. This project systematically investigated a novel mechanism of heat conduction—polaritonic heat transfer—which leverages unique surface-bound electromagnetic waves to enhance thermal conductivity at the nanoscale. Our research focused on surface phonon polaritons (SPhPs) and Surface Plasmon Polaritons (SPPs) in engineered nanostructures. These findings open new possibilities for managing heat in nanoscale devices and developing efficient energy transport technologies.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit

  1. Enhanced Thermal Conductivity in Nanoscale Structures
    Using silica (SiO₂) as a model system, we discovered that SPhPs significantly enhance thermal conductivity beyond conventional phonon limits. Our measurements showed that at elevated temperatures (550 K), thermal conductivity increased by 34% above the bulk SiO₂ limit—the first direct experimental evidence of SPhP-mediated heat conduction in nanostructures.
  2. Ballistic and Low-Dimensional Thermal Transport
    By analyzing nanoribbons of varying sizes, we observed that heat conduction exhibits ballistic transport behavior, meaning thermal energy propagates with minimal scattering. Our results also demonstrated the transition between one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) heat conduction, dependent on nanoribbon geometry. These insights contribute to the fundamental understanding of nanoscale energy transport and could lead to ultra-efficient thermal management strategies in electronics.
  3. Surface Plasmon Polaritons (SPPs) and Heat Transfer in Thin Metal Films
    In addition to SPhPs, we explored the role of SPPs in gold nanofilms, which are surface waves occurring at metal-dielectric interfaces. We found that localized SPPs in discontinuous gold films significantly contribute to heat conduction. By carefully tuning the nanostructure, we identified conditions under which SPPs enhance thermal transport, a promising result for applications in plasmonic energy conversion and nanoscale heat dissipation.

Broader Impacts

This research not only advances the fundamental science of thermal transport but also has broad implications for multiple fields, including microelectronics, photonics, and energy-efficient materials. The results could potentially contribute to:

  • Efficient Thermal Management in Electronics: As electronic devices continue to shrink, overheating becomes a major challenge. By harnessing SPhP and SPP-based conduction, future high-performance chips and optoelectronic devices could achieve better heat dissipation without increasing component size.
  • Sustainable Energy Applications: The ability to control and enhance heat conduction at the nanoscale could improve thermophotovoltaic systems, which convert waste heat into electricity. It may also lead to new radiative cooling technologies that passively manage temperature without additional energy consumption.
  • Interdisciplinary Impact: This project bridges thermal physics and nanophotonics, introducing novel heat transfer mechanisms that could influence fields like plasmonics, semiconductor materials, and energy conversion.

Educational and Training Contributions

The project provided valuable research opportunities for students at multiple academic levels:

  • Graduate and Postdoctoral Training: Two graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher were actively engaged in this work, gaining experience in nanofabrication, optical measurements, and thermal modeling. Their contributions have prepared them for future careers in academia and industry.
  • Undergraduate and High School Engagement: As part of outreach efforts, we mentored two undergraduate and three high school students, introducing them to cutting-edge thermal measurement techniques through UCSD’s Junior IDEA Scholar program. One undergraduate student received a GEAR Summer Research Scholarship to support their research in our lab.

Dissemination of Findings

The results of this work have been shared with the broader scientific community through:

  • Invited conference presentations at the Materials Research Society (MRS) Spring and Fall Meetings and the ASME Heat Transfer Conference.
  • Award-winning student presentations by graduate students, highlighting the contributions of early-career researchers.
  • Peer-reviewed publications in Nature Communications, Advanced Materials, and Advanced Materials Technology.

Conclusion

This project represents a major step forward in understanding polaritonic heat conduction, a previously underexplored mechanism for controlling thermal energy at the nanoscale. By demonstrating the feasibility of ballistic heat transport and quantized thermal conduction, our findings pave the way for next-generation thermal management technologies that could revolutionize energy efficiency in electronics and photonics.
